reviews.review_msg: Probably the most passionate prof I've seen about class material, very engaging in lectures and makes Game of Thrones references a lot. Main cons are that material is sometimes unorganised because he goes on work trips during semester etc., and gives a lot of assignments compared to 255, which each take a lot of time.
dry lecture, ambiguous guildline of assignment. unclear grading criteria.

Very good prof. He has interesting things to show and tell you, and he is obviously involved in his work. The amount of work required for an A tho will be quite a lot. And if you seek for more clarification, you *might* get even more confused. Stressful to work on his projects, but the payoff is awesome once those are done and you put work in them

Just like in Geog 255 Nick is expecting quality grade projects. The project in 356 is your own now. You must find all the necessary data and find methods to build it. Project represents 50%. Nick will always point out the good stuff about your project, even if the project looks average at best. He is very supportive of the end result

Lectures are pretty useless but you do learn some cool things. Labs are time consuming but informative and are graded rather easily. Nick's expectations for the final project are a little too high, though. He'll offer you subtle hints but won't actually help you.
Pushes you to work hard. Learn the coolest cutting edge issues in GIS. Buys the Beers afterwords! Whats not to like?

Nick is VERY interested in the subject matter and is enthusiastic. He has very high expectations and often labs will take 9-10 hours to complete. The final project will consume your life! If you work hard,  you get a good mark and come out with a cool project.
